Examination of the issues of foreign exchange and country risk as they apply to firms operating across national boundaries and various management techniques and approaches used to manage such risks.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A focus on concepts and tools used in covering financial risks of investments and financial transactions. The paper will include study of modern financial derivatives and their usage in reducing risk. Additionally, the paper demonstrates the relevance of finance theory and techniques to New Zealand businesses operating within global markets.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: To provide students with an applied view of finance for entrepreneurs, start-ups and small firms. It offers an integrated set of concepts and applications from finance, entrepreneurship, and accounting theories and practices. The paper will prepare students for the challenges facing young and innovative firms.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Introduces students to the application of various financial models within the context of excel with a focus on applying the models to real-world situations.  Students will also be introduced to collecting financial data using several databases including DataStream, NZ Deep Archive and Osiris.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Wealth Management focuses on the process of developing and implementing a financial plan. Issues related to an investor's profile, their asset allocation strategies, insurance and taxation will be studied. Furthermore, the different characteristics and features of a range of financial instruments such as stocks, bonds, mutual funds, property and commodities will be explored.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Immersion in the food product development process using a product development team approach.  Identifies the processes and stages required to address a specific product development objective from concept to finished product.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Knowledge of the properties and uses of packaging materials and packaging procedures for foods; the ability to choose and evaluate packaging procedures and packaging materials and to monitor performance.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The reasons for and the development of food legislation in New Zealand; major food related legislation and enforcement agencies; the impact of international food law and trade agreements on our legislation; other factors that influence changes to our food laws.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A detailed study of the chemistry of selected food components, their identification, interactions, analysis, uses in formulations, and impact on society.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Provides an overview of sensory evaluation.  Covers special senses, as well as control of test room, samples and panel.  Reviews discriminative, descriptive and affective sensory methodolgies used to measure human perception and preference.  Description and measurement of the sensory characteristics of food products.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Methods to ensure food safety and provides students with the advanced skills to perform root cause analysis, food verification as well as auditing principles.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An introduction to the principles and applications of molecular genetics, gene manipulation and related technologies.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A study of global tectonic environments and the causal planetary forces that shape the earth. An examination of the deformation of the earth's crust including folding, faulting, mountain building, and the formation of continents and ocean basins. Comparisons with other planetary tectonic and deformation environments. Application of an understanding of rock engineering properties to urbanization, communications and mining.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A study of the major rock forming minerals and rock types in terms of their chemical composition and physical/biological character, mode of occurrence, and genetic environment. Comparisons of earth materials and those of other planetary bodies.  How earth materials are used by humans, including geo-resources such as economic minerals, metals, energy and water resources.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A study of the range of global volcanic environments and the fundamental causes for the variation in volcanic and magmatic environments. An examination of the links between volcanoes and planetary evolution on earth and other planets and links between volcanoes and humans.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An examination of geological hazards and risks, the natural processes that produce them and their impacts on the planet, the local environment and human society.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Critically examines diversity management using a multi-level macro (country/region), meso (organisational) and micro (individual) framework. Inequalities in work and organisations, and ways to build inclusiveness in organisational life are addressed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An examination of global mobility within an international and cross cultural context. Students will critically reflect on strategies driving internationalisation and the resultant organisational structures. International talent management, career models, HRM issues and practices for optimal and ethical organisational outcomes, future HRM trends and individual career management within a contemporary global labour market are also explored.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: In-depth examination of contemporary issues in the global business environment and business. The implications for MNEs, countries and the future of international business will be addressed. The paper will require students to take a critical perspective on current global developments in the management of international firms, trade and the global business environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: This paper advances strategic management knowledge and skills to deepen understanding of international business strategy and implementation in challenging, dynamic and complex global contexts. The paper focuses on developing advanced business research skills to formulate strategic management insight for decision-making.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: This advanced paper examines the processes of innovation within established corporations. Types and modes of innovation and appropriation regimes are explored.  The paper examines corporate entrepreneurship, how firms grow through alliances, networks and acquisition of start-ups. Issues around managing technology transfer, born-global firms and supporting innovation are examined.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Builds marketing and market insights to design, develop and evaluate appropriate strategies and tactics for successful marketing performance.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Develops an appreciation through marketing, advertising, retailing and sales insights of the elements and influencers that enable effective recognition, construction and formulation of communications in an omni-channel environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
paper_name: Digital, Social Media and Mobile Marketing
prescriptor: An applied paper framed by relevant marketing theory and emerging theoretical insights exploring how the digital transformation of marketing is reflected in novel market behaviours, consumer interactions and experiences, and how the work of marketers will continue to evolve in a post-digital environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Explores the way companies are designing their brand strategies, points of differentiation, positioning and brand names to attract sports consumers and participants. Develops an understanding of the value of marketing from the sponsor/brand side and emphasizes the elements critical to effective, multifocal and strategic marketing in sports. Structured around the management of sports brands and examines sports consumers' cognitive, emotional and behavioural responses to those brands.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The paper concerns international sales management in both bricks and mortar and online service organisations. It covers a wide range of strategic and operational decisions in contemporary global business environments. Industry best practices in professional sales management and global example cases (including tied agents, brokers and independent contractors) are discussed throughout the paper.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Explore insights into media channel planning and implementation in communication strategies from the perspective of consumer psychology. Topics include the role of media in strengthening involvement between consumers and brands through the management of media strategy in advertising. Topics are evaluated in the context of an explosion of new communication opportunities and the consumer's changing lifestyles.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: To critically evaluate the changing retail landscape and ways in which retailers and retail designers can create retail experiences that enables them to operate profitably and in a socially conscious way.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Develops an appreciation through marketing, advertising, retailing and sales insights of the elements and influencers that enable effective recognition, construction and formulation of communications in an omni-channel environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
paper_name: Digital, Social Media and Mobile Marketing B
prescriptor: An applied paper framed by relevant marketing theory and emerging theoretical insights exploring how the digital transformation of marketing is reflected in novel market behaviours, consumer interactions and experiences, and how the work of marketers will continue to evolve in a post-digital environment.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Advanced mathematical models in the areas of financial mathematics. Apply mathematical concepts and analytic techniques to solve financial, engineering and/or industrial problems.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Develops skills in the interpretation and use of numerical methods appropriate to engineering and science, and in the development of computer programs using numerical techniques.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Investigates linear partial differential equations in one, two, and three dimensions, including analytic techniques for solving partial differential equations and their applications.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An investigation into a scientific problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The practice of diagnostic molecular genetics.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An in-depth examination of the complex interdependency of private, public and Not-for-Profit organisations and wider societal concerns. Using a broader set of questions the meanings and reciprocal nature of social impact management is explored. A critical lens examines a selection of contemporary issues to gauge the implications of business decisions on interpretations of social impact.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An examination of stress and resilience at work, including theoretical models. Students will critically evaluate the causes and consequences of stress and resilience. A range of approaches to managing stress and improving resilience at work are explored.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Provide students with an understanding of, and ability, to apply risk management principles, frameworks, processes and techniques in different settings.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
paper_name: Organising for the Future of Work
prescriptor: An in-depth examination of the contemporary and future work environments. Students will critically reflect on how a changing world requires new approaches to organisation, management and leadership.  Digital transformation and innovation  will also be examined for how they influence the nature of work and society at the individual and organisational level.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The application of scientific and engineering principles to the processing of material by biological agents (i.e. microbial plant, animal cells and enzymes); the processing of biological materials such as food, medicine and chemicals; how a living cell performs a specific useful task in a predictable and controllable way.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An understanding of the microbial ecology of foods and the role of micro-organisms in food production; problems associated with sampling and micro-biological analysis of foods;  interpretation of micro-biological data; development of an assurance programme in food preparation and food manufacture.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Explores the pharmacology of commonly used drugs and the application of this to various clinical situations.  Considers the responsibilities of the health professional in relation to drug therapy and with regard to political, social, and cultural considerations, pharmacology science, legislation, and ethical practice.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The first part of the paper provides an overview of concepts, theories and experimental research in behavioural psychology. The second part shows how these concepts can be applied in behaviour therapy, particularly with reference to autistic spectrum disorders and general learning disabilities.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The paper aims to stimulate further interest in psychology, and to increase the student's ability and skills to be flexible thinkers.  In addition to developing the ability to separate fact from opinion, the paper will assist the student to view topics from diverse and often contradictory theoretical perspectives.  The paper will also introduce students to the wide range of personal, professional and social issues to which psychological theory can be applied in modern life.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
paper_name: Experimental and Applied Behaviour Analysis II
prescriptor: Examines current research and theories in the Experimental Analysis of Behaviour and current research and practice in Applied Behaviour Analysis.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: This paper draws upon human and animal research to provide an overview of biological approaches (evolutionary, physiology, neuroscience) to understanding normal and abnormal behaviour.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: This paper has three inter-dependent components; an introduction to the emerging field of positive psychology which is the scientific study of the strengths and virtues that enable individuals and communities to thrive; an analysis of the definitions, measurement, and applications of the concepts of quality of life, wellbeing and happiness; and the application of positive psychology to mental health recovery processes and approaches including psychological counselling.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Introduction to the range and scope of health psychology practice and research.  Topics covered include health-enhancing and compromising behaviours, patient-doctor relationships, coping with illness, and dealing with stress.  The use of psychological research to address public health and wellbeing issues in society will be reviewed.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Provides an overview of different theories and approaches to psychological intervention.  Examines theoretical principles which inform practice with different client groups in Aotearoa/New Zealand.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Are human beings selfish and competitive by nature or are we naturally caring and cooperative? Are human beings rational? Can we control our emotions? Should we control them? These empirical questions and others relating to human nature will be addressed in the light of scientific theories, current research and debates in the area of emotions. The development in the students of a concept of human nature informed by the latest research in psychology and evolutionary theory will be encouraged.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
paper_name: Applied Issues in Cultural and Social Psychology
prescriptor: Provides an overview of concepts, theories and research in the field of cultural and social psychology.  Fosters an understanding about important issues in areas such as intergroup relations, multiculturalism, conflict resolution, the law and the developing world, individualism and collectivism, group dynamics, 'abnormal' psychology and culture, gender and sexuality, social cognition, affiliation and friendship, romantic relationships, and prosocial behaviour.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An investigation into a scientific or technological problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A placement in industry structured to provide an opportunity for students to reflect critically on the relationship between their academic studies and business practice by an original investigation into a scientific problem or development work from an industrial project.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Pharmacology of anaesthetic agents; anaesthetic management; fluids and blood; emergency situations.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Training in management of complex procedures in Anaesthetic Technology at an advanced level through supervised work experience; theoretical teaching in the clinical setting; completion of practical tasks through log books and practical assessments.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The paper is intended for students who have a special interest in a topic that is relevant to their course of study when a suitable paper is not offered.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: A scientific investigation into sustainable development that may be experimental, empirical or literature based.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: The focus of this paper is the application of stochastic models to analyse real-life scenarios.  Key stochastic processes are studied via their mathematical properties and simulation. Models are fitted to data taken from a range of applications.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: An introduction to data management for analytics suitable for applications in business, finance, industry, and government.  Topics include: querying, cleaning, manipulating, and displaying data;   programming skills and methods suitable for handling large data sets.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Collection and analysis of data in an industrial and business context. Control charts, experimental design, samples and surveys. Analysis of data using analytics software.

qualification_name: Bachelor of Business and Bachelor of Science Conjoint Degrees
prescriptor: Student - staff partnership' advances the idea of students as co-creators of knowledge and involves students directly in curriculum. Students will function as program consultants to the SUSE Major and manage their own AUT curriculum related projects within it. Through implementation students gain practical experience from designing their own learning goals, setting assessment criteria, and evaluating and sharing their learning. The project can involve exploring new opportunities, reviewing existing processes, educating level 5 and 6 students and evaluating performance.

An introduction to applied statistics. Topics include: summary statistics, plotting data, the Normal distribution, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, basic statistical computing, simulation, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, and the detection of outliers.

Introduces students to the wonders of the Universe and equips them with the basic concepts and principles of astronomy. Describes and explains cosmic cycles and 'rhythms', the origin of matter and time, formation of galaxies, stars and the Earth. An introduction to the history of astronomy and Maori cosmology will provide an appreciation of the contemporary place of astronomy and a framework for understanding how the modern body of astronomy knowledge has developed.
The nature of biological variability, sampling, analysis and interpreting of data.
An introduction to the structure and function of cells, plants and animals.  Common processes considered include: protection, reproduction, respiration, nutrition and communication.

A discussion of selected topics in chemistry relevant to biological systems: acids, bases and buffers, pH titrations, redox reactions and electrochemistry, alcohols, amines, aldehydes, ketones, and carboxylic acids, biomolecules, spectroscopy and mass spectrometry.

Skills and capabilities based on theoretical knowledge in the areas of written, oral, interpersonal and group communication. The content of the course is at all stages made relevant to the students needs both for their course of study and their role in the workplace.

Presents an integrated approach to data communications and computer networking principles, building on IT infrastructure concepts. These concepts are applied in a network environment starting with the application layer and progressing through to the data link layer.

Introduces programming concepts through the use of structured scripting to move and manipulate multimedia objects, such as images, audio and video files. Aspects of interpreting system feedback, identifying errors and developing coding best practice are also covered.  This elective paper provides students with an opportunity to learn and practice programming through structured activities that can be built on in more advanced programming papers.
An introduction to evolutionary and ecological patterns and processes.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.
Introduces the process of program design and implementation using object-oriented programming, with particular emphasis on applications from Computer Science and engineering technology.
The evolution of life on Earth, the geophysical and anthropogenic effects on evolution and extinction and the unique position of New Zealand Biota within the global evolutionary trajectory.

A description of the basic forces governing the distribution and flow of mass and energy over the Earth's surface, the relationship between earths systems and society and the implications of these for environmental management.
A description of how planet Earth works, what makes it a living planet and what shaped its surface.
Provides an overview of the relationships among humans and the environment relating to differences in development, land use, economic systems and socio-cultural values.
An introduction to the causes, patterns of development and surveillance of diseases within populations.
An understanding of the nature and properties of foods and the nutritional requirements of humans; the major causes of food spoilage; an overview of major food processing procedures.
Introduces the fundamental concepts of human anatomy and physiology.
Introduces the principles of communication, knowledge, academic and scientific literacy.
Introduces global health and environmental issues and applies these in the context of Aotearoa New Zealand
Provides an introduction to Maori concepts of health and environment and their implications for practice.  Fosters critical enquiry into and reflection on Maori health and links to Maori development.

Provides an introduction to the mathematical concepts required for an understanding of the analysis of data and applications in computing, science, and engineering. Topics include: sets, functions, series, limits, calculus, probability and statistics.
Gives the student an understanding of differential and integral calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of simple engineering and scientific systems.

Gives the student a solid foundation in algebra and discrete mathematics, providing essential background for further study in many fields of Science and Engineering, particularly those utilizing ideas from Mathematics or Computer Science.
An introduction to the diagnostic disciplines of Histology and Cytology with emphasis on techniques and methodology.
An introduction to the classification, bacterial anatomy and physiology, cultivation, staining and identification of micro-organisms.

A general, calculus-based classical physics course. The topics covered are: particle kinematics, Newtonian dynamics, work and energy, gravitation, collisions and momentum, torque and angular momentum, rigid-body statics and dynamics, harmonic oscillations, mechanical waves, sound waves, thermal processes, laws of thermodynamics, entropy.

Overview of psychology covering the principles, theories, applications and methodologies of psychological practice and research.  Students will develop an awareness of the diversity and relevance of the discipline.  The paper serves both as a stand-alone paper introducing psychology to students from a range of disciplines, and a foundation in psychology as preparation for later study.
A second introductory paper in psychology that complements and extends Introduction to Psychology A.

Introduces the student to the methods and concepts of  psychology. The strengths and limitations of the various perspectives that have been developed to explain human behaviour will be critically examined using relevant experiments and studies. The course content is designed to illuminate the complementary nature of psychological models and the workings of the scientific method.
Introduces the student to professional practice, health and safety, and microbiology in the clinical setting, the history and principles of anaesthesia, and patient care.

Training in equipment in anaesthetic technology through supervised work experience; theoretical teaching in a clinical setting: the completion of practical tasks through logbooks and practical assessment.
Principles of physics with an emphasis on biological applications, measurement and instrumentation.

An introduction to applied statistics. Provides techniques for describing and summarising a data set. Delivers an understanding of how to use a sample to infer the properties of the population it was taken from. Students in this course also learn how to use statistical software to undertake descriptive analysis as well as perform statistical inference.

The techniques of spherical trigonometry will be applied to the analysis of problems of positional astronomy. Topics include coordinate systems and their transformations, parallax, precession and aberration, sidereal time, time-keeping and calendar, as well as the basics of celestial mechanics such as Kepler's laws, two-body orbital motion, and binary star orbits. The paper emphasises computational aspects of spherical (positional) astronomy.

The fundamental concepts and principles of astrophysics are examined developing an understanding of and problem solving skills in radioactive processes, stellar structures and evolution, physics of the Solar System, galactic structure and evolution, and cosmology.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of plants and animals within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction, and general ecology.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of fish and plants within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction and general ecology.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of plans and animals within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction, and general ecology.

A study of topics in inorganic chemistry: coordination and p-block chemistry, molecular symmetry, molecular orbital theory, and bioinorganic chemistry.

A general overview of biochemistry: the properties of enzymes; photosynthesis; metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates; nitrogen and amino acid metabolism; nucleic acids and protein synthesis. Cell membrane and wall structure and function.

An introduction to the fundamentals of the chemistry of organic compounds: structure, bonding and reactions of the major functional groups; occurrence, uses and synthesis of organic compounds using selected examples of natural and synthetic materials.
The analytical chemistry of foods and food-like matrices such as water and soils. Classical methods, international standard methods and an introduction to modern instrumental analysis.
A study of fundamental concepts in physical chemistry including thermodynamics, kinetics and quantum theory.

A discussion of selected topics in coordination chemistry: formation and properties of coordination complexes, common experimental techniques, the crystal field model, electronic spectroscopy, magnetism and molecular orbital theory.

An introduction to the design and construction of object- oriented software. It will extend individual design and programming skills developed in earlier programming papers, with an emphasis on the quality, modularity and reusability of the software developed. The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

The paper will introduce current techniques used in software development that allow the goals of software development projects to be realised.

Theoretical and practical skills for the utilisation of mathematical structures and algorithms for handling data that are essential in computational mathematics and computer science. Static and dynamic structures for data, cloning data, mathematical concepts of iteration and recursion, analysis of performance and complexity, data searching and data sorting algorithms, mathematical logic and formal grammars.
Algorithmic analysis, concurrency algorithms, design patterns, design techniques, advanced data structures, graph algorithms, numerical algorithms.

A practical foundation in high-level computer graphics programming and a comprehensive overview of proven graphics algorithms and software techniques is presented with a focus on those techniques that have become common currency in the field of interactive computer graphics.
An introduction to the logical and combinatorial tools and methods used in mathematics and computer science, with an emphasis on axiomatic systems, combinatorial principles, and automated reasoning.
The planning and implementation of conservation initiatives.
An overview of limnology: the physical, chemical and biological characteristics of freshwater habitats; freshwater ecology; field survey techniques; analysis of field data.

An understanding of community concepts especially in relation to the evolutionary and historical context of NZ terrestrial biota; collection of terrestrial field data, its analysis and presentation;  critical assessment of ecological concepts; methods for sampling terrestrial animals.
An introduction to concepts relating to sustainable resource management and an understanding of New Zealand and international environmental law.

Main techniques for measuring environmental quality:  water, air; the design of suitable sample regimes; interpretation of results.  Concepts of probability and consequence; qualitative and quantitative assessments of risk; computer software for risk assessment.
Develops understanding of the theory and practice of environmental health.  Covers environmental impact on human health; law, policies and procedures for environmental health management.
An introduction to Geographical Information Systems applications in science and technology as a tool for environmental and social planning.
The patterns and explanations of geographic variation in life on Earth are explored.

Explores current and best practice models for planning for environmental sustainability.   Appropriate technologies in different socio-cultural and environmental settings will be explored in depth.  Planning and policy development paradigms in New Zealand and internationally will be analysed.
Overview of taxonomic classification systems and development of skills necessary for identifying plant and animal species.
A basis for the understanding of the chemistry of food components, human nutrition and biochemistry; basic analytical procedures for foods.

This paper is designed to provide students with an understanding of the role of microorganisms in food spoilage, food preservation and food borne disease, and to develop proficiency in the practice of food microbiology.
This paper is offered as a combination of structured teacher input sessions (lectures and tutorials) and practical work.
An overview of process engineering:  the application of the principles of measurement, heat transfer, fluid flow, materials handling and process engineering in the chemical and food industries.
The concepts, processes and applications of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genetics and evolution.
The structure and function of nucleic acids, proteins, genes and genomes.

An examination of the linkages between geology and geological processes, landscape, environment and the living world, including modern human society.  A close examination of plate tectonic processes that produce mountains, rift valleys and ocean basins.  How surface processes sculpt these features creating a diverse range of environments that influence life and its development on planet earth.
An examination of sedimentary rocks, their genesis and formation, and the environments in which they form.
Develops and applies concepts from Human Anatomy and Physiology I and incorporates basic concepts of microbiology and pharmacology.
Develops knowledge of the enquiry process and an applied understanding of qualitative and quantitative research design.

Provides students with the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of database management systems. Specifically, the paper provides an in-depth understanding of data modelling and database design concepts. The retrieval language will be covered in detail. The balanced approach of theory and practice will provide students with a better understanding of the issues and problems involved in database design and development.
Provides the student with a solid foundation in linear algebra and its applications.
Gives the student a solid understanding of advanced calculus, and develops the ability to formulate and solve models of complex engineering and scientific systems.
A foundation in linear algebra. Solving and applying ordinary, partial and systems of differential equations.
The elements of actuarial mathematics: securities, annuities, mortality laws, life annuities, life insurance policy values.

Micro-organisms and their relationship to the disease process, their isolation and identification using culture media and biochemical tests; some commonly encountered pathogenic micro-organisms, their clinical significance and laboratory diagnosis; methods of sterilisation, disinfection, microscopy, enumeration, urinalysis.

An understanding of how the growth and activities of micro-organisms in natural environments such as soil, water and air, affect peoples quality of life. The design of acceptable scientific solutions to problems in pollution control, public health, agriculture and resource recovery.

The utilisation of micro-organisms and microbial processes to produce economically important products such as food, industrial chemicals and pharmaceuticals; understanding of the technologies associated with commercial production of microbial metabolites; the relevance of the growth and activity of micro-organisms to the national economy and to our quality of life.

The history of communicable and infectious diseases, the key diseases and their sources, investigation and prevalence of disease, infection control and disease prevention, surveillance, and the collection of samples and specimens.

A calculus-based general physics paper. The topics covered include: Electro- and magnetostatics, DC and AC circuits, time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, geometric optics, interference and diffraction, the quantum nature of particles and light, atomic and nuclear phenomena.

Gives an overview of the main psychological disorders and provides an understanding of classification, diagnosis, aetiology/causality, and treatment. These issues will be discussed in the context of the social construction of psychopathology.

Describes the scope and application of social psychology. Considers how the individual behaves in the presence, or perceived presence of others, and introduces students to the study of social interaction and the ways in which people influence one another.

This paper will introduce students to the field of psychological assessment including how to gather quantitative and qualitative information from interviews, observing behaviour and psychological testing. The purposes, formulation, construction, and administration of assessment strategies will be analysed, while introducing the student to a variety of psychological tests.

A critical understanding of alternative definitions and conceptualisations of personality across the lifespan will be fostered, and an overview of major personality theories as explanatory models provided. Current issues in personality theory and research will be reviewed. The implications of major theories of personality for personality assessment and psychological practices which promote change across the lifespan will be considered.

Provides an overview of concepts, theories, and research practices associated with the behavioural and biological paradigms in psychology.  Discussion focuses on contemporary psychological and social issues.

A review of theoretical perspectives regarding how individuals make sense of the person in a social world, and how they develop their personality, self-concept, and social behaviour. Using a social and personality psychology framework, it will review how the concept of self is acquired and influences behaviour. It will also review the central role of the self-concept in different theories of personality and abnormal behaviour.

Perception and memory are the processes through which we construct the representations of ourselves and the world which make up our minds.  These representations guide subsequent perceptions, problem solving and decision making processes, both conscious and unconscious.  Through language we relate to our social environment.  Current theory and experimental research in cognitive psychology dealing with these concepts and processes will be covered, as well as applications in professional contexts.
An overview of physical and mechanical testing techniques: industry specific test methods plus standard methods.
Knowledge and practical skills in advanced research techniques.
Introduces the student to basic assessment of the peri-operative patient and relates aspects of intra-operative patient care to anaesthetic practice.
Introduces the student to the operating principles of anaesthetic equipment, including monitoring.

paper_name: Graphs R Us: Data Visualisation with R
prescriptor: Empowers students to explore data graphically and to communicate research findings clearly and efficiently with compelling, publication-quality figures.

Provides an introduction to a branch of statistics that deals with the study of chance. Delivers access to a range of techniques for modelling and analysing probability problems in real-life settings.
A study of statistical methods suitable for a range of applications in science, engineering and business.
Development of awareness of the philosophies of Quality Management; statistical and organisational techniques for establishing, maintaining and improving quality.

An introduction to forecasting in business and economics using statistical models. Making predictions from data that arise sequentially in time (e.g. annual electricity production, unemployment rates, share prices, global temperature series). Topics include forecasting strategies, detecting trends, autoregressive models, and simulation.

The principles and practice of observational astronomy and astrophysics with a focus on the design and synthesis of instruments for specific observational programmes. Topics include telescopes (including optical and radio), multi-wavelength radiation detectors, gravitational and neutrino detectors, methods of CCD photometry and astrometry, principles and methods of spectroscopy and astronomical data analysis techniques, .polarimetry, magnetometry and solar observational techniques.

Provides an understanding of the principles and practice of Radio Astronomy starting from a review of the radio astronomical Universe: the Sun and planets, gaseous nebulae, pulsars, masers, radio galaxies and quasars and cosmic microwave background radiation. Topics include radio spectroscopy, the design of radio telescopes and the application of interferometric techniques to the analysis of synthesis imaging

Examines different aspects of modern astronomy and astrophysics by surveying topics that are at the cutting edge of current research. Topics include microarcsecond astrometry, numerical and quantum cosmology, microlensing, exoplanets, active galactic nuclei and relativistic jets, X-ray and Gamma-ray astronomy, dark matter and dark energy, pulsars and magnetars, SETI, optical and radio telescopes of the future.
Integrates understanding and application of the principles and concepts of the geology, chemistry, physics, and biology of oceans.

Advanced multi-disciplinary research in the marine environment, including ocean dynamics, biological interactions within animal and plant communities, and their unique adaptations to various physical environments; sampling and experimentation within a variety of marine ecosystems.
An analysis of health protection activities to meet public health service requirements and regulatory   service guidelines relevant to key areas of public health.
Explanation of the importance of natural compounds in biomedical science and industry. Investigation and application of natural compounds.
Explore advanced methods used for biomedical research and understand the protocol to conduct biomedical research.
Explore the technologies used in biomedical research including: nano-technology, microencapsulation, smart biomaterials, 3D printing and bio-printing.

An overview of natural products; extraction, isolation and purification; classes, general structures, biosynthesis, function and uses.  Chemical synthesis, analysis and spectroscopy of selected natural products and derivatives.

Selected aspects of analytical chemistry: mass spectrometry as an analytical rather than a structural tool, separation science, electroanalytical chemistry, molecular and atomic spectroscopy, infrared (mid and near) spectrophotometry, automated analysis.
Key environmental, inorganic and physical processes in the environment.  Chemistry, exposure to and mitigation of selected pollutants.
The driving forces and mechanisms behind organic reactions.  The mechanistic chemistry of the major functional groups.  Organic synthesis.

An examination of the physical chemistry of interfaces, colloids and self-assembled structures. The principles of nanoscience are introduced including the preparation and analysis of nanomaterials and their application to nanotechnology.

A study of advanced topics in inorganic chemistry: electronic spectroscopy, reaction mechanisms, molecular orbital theory applied to polyatomic molecules, organometallic chemistry and catalysis, and the periodic trends of groups 1, 2, 13 and 14.
A study of advanced topics in biochemistry including protein expression and purification, protein stability and dynamics, enzyme kinetics and mechanisms, biosignaling and selected metabolic pathways.
An overview of recently emerging topics in organic chemistry including green chemistry, retrosynthesis of natural products, supramolecular chemistry and synthesis in unconventional media.
A practical foundation in game programming, using a variety of game development tools and programming libraries, and deploying games on a variety of platforms.

A rigorous exploration into the Theory of Computer Science providing a mathematically sound presentation of the theory of computer science including formal languages and models of computation, as well as an introduction to computational complexity.
Surveys the theoretical and practical aspects of modern programming languages, including their design and implementation, program translation, virtual machines, and different programming pradigms.
Investigates the design and implementation of distributed systems, including contemporary technologies such as Java Enterprise Edition and .NET, as well as the development of mobile systems.
Provides an in-depth understanding of LAN, WAN and Wireless security focusing on the functionality available and configuration of network and link layers.
The aim of this paper is to understand the nature of intelligent systems and how such a system may be implemented.
Furthers understanding of the factors (psychological, ergonomic, organisational, social etc) that determine how people operate and make use of computer technology effectively.

Introduces students to the exciting world of Data Mining. Organisations have, over time, accumulated vast amounts of valuable data which, when exploited appropriately will give them a significant competitive advantage over their rivals who merely "crunch" data. Data Mining is an area that has come of age - well proven techniques and tools are widely available. Covers popular mining techniques as well as providing specific hands-on experience using a publicly available tool.
An integrated understanding of the scientific, political, legal and ethical issues associated with contemporary natural resource conservation in New Zealand.

The conservation of threatened or endangered megafauna will be studied within reserves, while field
techniques will be utilised to collect data on their biology, ecology and management.

The development of skills in conducting a plant ecology field study: the collection and presentation of data. The influence of disturbance and soils on forest dynamics, patterns and causes of plant species diversity and plant Physiology.

The explanation of evolutionary drivers of animal behaviour and the practical implications of behavioural traits for conservation. The development of an understanding of animal behaviour research and practical experience in the collection of behavioural data.

An investigation of the ecology and biology of tropical marine and terrestrial ecosystems utilising practical field techniques, experimental design and analytical skills to assess the impact of human populations on these ecosystems.

This paper aims to further develop your understanding of the concepts and methods required for the construction of large software intensive systems. The paper develops a broader understanding of the discipline of software engineering to provide exposure to the full range of techniques and processes associated with the development of complex software intensive systems.

Understanding of the geomorphology, ecosystems and resources associated with terrestrial, coastal and marine environments.  Critical assessment of the issues associated with resource allocation and use and the range of techniques utilized in the management of natural resources.
The use of advanced geo-spatial analysis tools for environmental management, decision support and geo-spatial planning.
Explore methods for determining the links between conservation of biodiversity, the attitudes and aspirations of people, and the success of conservation projects.

An in-depth understanding of the technical, theoretical and applied aspects of remote sensing theory as an important spatially based tool for conservation, decision support and natural resource planning and management.

Immersion in the food product development process using a product development team approach.  Identifies the processes and stages required to address a specific product development objective from concept to finished product.

Knowledge of the properties and uses of packaging materials and packaging procedures for foods; the ability to choose and evaluate packaging procedures and packaging materials and to monitor performance.

The reasons for and the development of food legislation in New Zealand; major food related legislation and enforcement agencies; the impact of international food law and trade agreements on our legislation; other factors that influence changes to our food laws.
A detailed study of the chemistry of selected food components, their identification, interactions, analysis, uses in formulations, and impact on society.

Provides an overview of sensory evaluation.  Covers special senses, as well as control of test room, samples and panel.  Reviews discriminative, descriptive and affective sensory methodolgies used to measure human perception and preference.  Description and measurement of the sensory characteristics of food products.
Methods to ensure food safety and provides students with the advanced skills to perform root cause analysis, food verification as well as auditing principles.
An introduction to the principles and applications of molecular genetics, gene manipulation and related technologies.
An overview of the concepts, processes and applications of molecular diagnostics
The concepts and processes of bioinformatics.
The processes used by microorganisms to survive and respond to their environments.  Molecular based methods for analysing microbial communities, genomes and their evolutionary relationships.

A study of global tectonic environments and the causal planetary forces that shape the earth. An examination of the deformation of the earth's crust including folding, faulting, mountain building, and the formation of continents and ocean basins. Comparisons with other planetary tectonic and deformation environments. Application of an understanding of rock engineering properties to urbanization, communications and mining.

A study of the major rock forming minerals and rock types in terms of their chemical composition and physical/biological character, mode of occurrence, and genetic environment. Comparisons of earth materials and those of other planetary bodies.  How earth materials are used by humans, including geo-resources such as economic minerals, metals, energy and water resources.

A study of the range of global volcanic environments and the fundamental causes for the variation in volcanic and magmatic environments. An examination of the links between volcanoes and planetary evolution on earth and other planets and links between volcanoes and humans.
An examination of geological hazards and risks, the natural processes that produce them and their impacts on the planet, the local environment and human society.
Critical evaluation of the research process. Particular emphasis is placed on students learning how to engage in the research process and how to apply this knowledge to practice.
Advanced mathematical models in the areas of financial mathematics. Apply mathematical concepts and analytic techniques to solve financial, engineering and/or industrial problems.
To enable coverage of the mathematical sciences in the areas of applied mathematics, analytics, astronomy or computer science.
To permit further concentration on new emergent topics in the mathematical sciences on areas of special staff expertise or research interests.
Develops skills in the interpretation and use of numerical methods appropriate to engineering and science, and in the development of computer programs using numerical techniques.
Investigates linear partial differential equations in one, two, and three dimensions, including analytic techniques for solving partial differential equations and their applications.
An investigation into a scientific problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.
The practice of diagnostic molecular genetics.

The application of scientific and engineering principles to the processing of material by biological agents (i.e. microbial plant, animal cells and enzymes); the processing of biological materials such as food, medicine and chemicals; how a living cell performs a specific useful task in a predictable and controllable way.

An understanding of the microbial ecology of foods and the role of micro-organisms in food production; problems associated with sampling and micro-biological analysis of foods;  interpretation of micro-biological data; development of an assurance programme in food preparation and food manufacture.

Explores the pharmacology of commonly used drugs and the application of this to various clinical situations. The first part of the paper provides an overview of concepts, theories and experimental research in behavioural psychology. The second part shows how these concepts can be applied in behaviour therapy, particularly with reference to autistic spectrum disorders and general learning disabilities.

The paper aims to stimulate further interest in psychology, and to increase the student's ability and skills to be flexible thinkers.  In addition to developing the ability to separate fact from opinion, the paper will assist the student to view topics from diverse and often contradictory theoretical perspectives.  The paper will also introduce students to the wide range of personal, professional and social issues to which psychological theory can be applied in modern life.

paper_name: Experimental and Applied Behaviour Analysis II
prescriptor: Examines current research and theories in the Experimental Analysis of Behaviour and current research and practice in Applied Behaviour Analysis.
This paper draws upon human and animal research to provide an overview of biological approaches (evolutionary, physiology, neuroscience) to understanding normal and abnormal behaviour.

This paper has three inter-dependent components; an introduction to the emerging field of positive psychology which is the scientific study of the strengths and virtues that enable individuals and communities to thrive; an analysis of the definitions, measurement, and applications of the concepts of quality of life, wellbeing and happiness; and the application of positive psychology to mental health recovery processes and approaches including psychological counselling.

Introduction to the range and scope of health psychology practice and research.  Topics covered include health-enhancing and compromising behaviours, patient-doctor relationships, coping with illness, and dealing with stress.  The use of psychological research to address public health and wellbeing issues in society will be reviewed.
Provides an overview of different theories and approaches to psychological intervention.  Examines theoretical principles which inform practice with different client groups in Aotearoa/New Zealand.

Are human beings selfish and competitive by nature or are we naturally caring and cooperative? Are human beings rational? Can we control our emotions? Should we control them? These empirical questions and others relating to human nature will be addressed in the light of scientific theories, current research and debates in the area of emotions. The development in the students of a concept of human nature informed by the latest research in psychology and evolutionary theory will be encouraged.

paper_name: Applied Issues in Cultural and Social Psychology
prescriptor: Provides an overview of concepts, theories and research in the field of cultural and social psychology.  Fosters an understanding about important issues in areas such as intergroup relations, multiculturalism, conflict resolution, the law and the developing world, individualism and collectivism, group dynamics, 'abnormal' psychology and culture, gender and sexuality, social cognition, affiliation and friendship, romantic relationships, and prosocial behaviour.

An investigation into a scientific or technological problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.
Pharmacology of anaesthetic agents; anaesthetic management; fluids and blood; emergency situations.

Training in management of complex procedures in Anaesthetic Technology at an advanced level through supervised work experience; theoretical teaching in the clinical setting; completion of practical tasks through log books and practical assessments.

A scientific investigation into sustainable development that may be experimental, empirical or literature based.

The focus of this paper is the application of stochastic models to analyse real-life scenarios.  Key stochastic processes are studied via their mathematical properties and simulation. Models are fitted to data taken from a range of applications.

An introduction to data management for analytics suitable for applications in business, finance, industry, and government.  Topics include: querying, cleaning, manipulating, and displaying data;   programming skills and methods suitable for handling large data sets.

Principles of physics with an emphasis on biological applications, measurement and instrumentation.

The history of anaesthesia, anaesthetic equipment, patient monitoring, practical aspects of sterilisation and disinfection.
The technician's role in fluid administration, emergency anaesthetic situations, general and regional anaesthesia, patient care.

A discussion of selected topics in chemistry relevant to biological systems: acids, bases and buffers, pH titrations, redox reactions and electrochemistry, alcohols, amines, aldehydes, ketones, and carboxylic acids, biomolecules, spectroscopy and mass spectrometry.

Provides hands-on marine biology experience and research techniques; introduces marine and associated terrestrial habitats and their conservation, and the functioning of aquariums and aquaculture systems.
An introduction to evolutionary and ecological patterns and processes.
The evolution of life on Earth, the geophysical and anthropogenic effects on evolution and extinction and the unique position of New Zealand Biota within the global evolutionary trajectory.

An introduction to the causes, patterns of development and surveillance of diseases within populations.

Introduces the fundamental concepts of human anatomy and physiology.

An introduction to the classification, bacterial anatomy and physiology, cultivation, staining and identification of micro-organisms.

Training in equipment in anaesthetic technology through supervised work experience; theoretical teaching in a clinical setting: the completion of practical tasks through logbooks and practical assessment.
Principles of physics with an emphasis on biological applications, measurement and instrumentation.

An introduction to applied statistics. Provides techniques for describing and summarising a data set. Delivers an understanding of how to use a sample to infer the properties of the population it was taken from. Students in this course also learn how to use statistical software to undertake descriptive analysis as well as perform statistical inference.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of plants and animals within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction, and general ecology.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of fish and plants within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction and general ecology.
Investigation of life histories and ecological adaptations of plans and animals within the marine environment; systematics, anatomy, physiology, life cycles, reproduction, and general ecology.

New Zealand and world-wide aquaculture industries; seafood production in hatcheries and farms; aquaculture practices from spawning to harvest of molluscs, fish, crustaceans, algae, and various culture feed species; life histories of cultured marine species; aspects of broodstock condition/induction, larval production, juvenile rearing, on-growing; food requirements for commercially important species; current issues impacting on aquaculture development.

paper_name: Health and Nutrition of Aquatic Organisms
prescriptor: Animal health and nutrition; health management aspects including disease diagnosis and treatment, and host-environment and pathogen relationships for a variety of aquatic animals; nutrition aspects; current problems and future research directions in health and nutrition of aquatic organisms with particular relevance to New Zealand industries.
A study of topics in inorganic chemistry: coordination and p-block chemistry, molecular symmetry, molecular orbital theory, and bioinorganic chemistry.

A general overview of biochemistry: the properties of enzymes; photosynthesis; metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates; nitrogen and amino acid metabolism; nucleic acids and protein synthesis. Cell membrane and wall structure and function.

An introduction to the fundamentals of the chemistry of organic compounds: structure, bonding and reactions of the major functional groups; occurrence, uses and synthesis of organic compounds using selected examples of natural and synthetic materials.
The analytical chemistry of foods and food-like matrices such as water and soils. Classical methods, international standard methods and an introduction to modern instrumental analysis.
A study of fundamental concepts in physical chemistry including thermodynamics, kinetics and quantum theory.
The planning and implementation of conservation initiatives.
An overview of limnology: the physical, chemical and biological characteristics of freshwater habitats; freshwater ecology; field survey techniques; analysis of field data.

An understanding of community concepts especially in relation to the evolutionary and historical context of NZ terrestrial biota; collection of terrestrial field data, its analysis and presentation;  critical assessment of ecological concepts; methods for sampling terrestrial animals.
An introduction to concepts relating to sustainable resource management and an understanding of New Zealand and international environmental law.

Main techniques for measuring environmental quality:  water, air; the design of suitable sample regimes; interpretation of results.  Concepts of probability and consequence; qualitative and quantitative assessments of risk; computer software for risk assessment.
Develops understanding of the theory and practice of environmental health.  Covers environmental impact on human health; law, policies and procedures for environmental health management.
An introduction to Geographical Information Systems applications in science and technology as a tool for environmental and social planning.
The patterns and explanations of geographic variation in life on Earth are explored.

Explores current and best practice models for planning for environmental sustainability.   Appropriate technologies in different socio-cultural and environmental settings will be explored in depth.  Planning and policy development paradigms in New Zealand and internationally will be analysed.
A basis for the understanding of the chemistry of food components, human nutrition and biochemistry; basic analytical procedures for foods.

This paper is offered as a combination of structured teacher input sessions (lectures and tutorials) and practical work.
An overview of process engineering:  the application of the principles of measurement, heat transfer, fluid flow, materials handling and process engineering in the chemical and food industries.
An overview of the concepts, processes and applications of classical, molecular and population genetics.
Develops and applies concepts from Human Anatomy and Physiology I and incorporates basic concepts of microbiology and pharmacology.
Develops knowledge of the enquiry process and an applied understanding of qualitative and quantitative research design.

Micro-organisms and their relationship to the disease process, their isolation and identification using culture media and biochemical tests; some commonly encountered pathogenic micro-organisms, their clinical significance and laboratory diagnosis; methods of sterilisation, disinfection, microscopy, enumeration, urinalysis.

An understanding of how the growth and activities of micro-organisms in natural environments such as soil, water and air, affect peoples quality of life. The design of acceptable scientific solutions to problems in pollution control, public health, agriculture and resource recovery.

The utilisation of micro-organisms and microbial processes to produce economically important products such as food, industrial chemicals and pharmaceuticals; understanding of the technologies associated with commercial production of microbial metabolites; the relevance of the growth and activity of micro-organisms to the national economy and to our quality of life.

The history of communicable and infectious diseases, the key diseases and their sources, investigation and prevalence of disease, infection control and disease prevention, surveillance, and the collection of samples and specimens.
An overview of physical and mechanical testing techniques: industry specific test methods plus standard methods.
Knowledge and practical skills in advanced research techniques.
Introduces the student to basic assessment of the peri-operative patient and relates aspects of intra-operative patient care to anaesthetic practice.
Introduces the student to the operating principles of anaesthetic equipment, including monitoring.

Advanced multi-disciplinary research in the marine environment, including ocean dynamics, biological interactions within animal and plant communities, and their unique adaptations to various physical environments; sampling and experimentation within a variety of marine ecosystems.
Integrates understanding and application of the principles and concepts of the geology, chemistry, physics, and biology of oceans.

Advanced multi-disciplinary research in the marine environment, including ocean dynamics, biological interactions within animal and plant communities, and their unique adaptations to various physical environments; sampling and experimentation within a variety of marine ecosystems.
An analysis of health protection activities to meet public health service requirements and regulatory   service guidelines relevant to key areas of public health.
Explanation of the importance of natural compounds in biomedical science and industry. Investigation and application of natural compounds.
Explore advanced methods used for biomedical research and understand the protocol to conduct biomedical research.
Explore the technologies used in biomedical research including: nano-technology, microencapsulation, smart biomaterials, 3D printing and bio-printing.

An overview of natural products; extraction, isolation and purification; classes, general structures, biosynthesis, function and uses.  Chemical synthesis, analysis and spectroscopy of selected natural products and derivatives.

Selected aspects of analytical chemistry: mass spectrometry as an analytical rather than a structural tool, separation science, electroanalytical chemistry, molecular and atomic spectroscopy, infrared (mid and near) spectrophotometry, automated analysis.
Key environmental, inorganic and physical processes in the environment.  Chemistry, exposure to and mitigation of selected pollutants.
The driving forces and mechanisms behind organic reactions.  The mechanistic chemistry of the major functional groups.  Organic synthesis.
An integrated understanding of the scientific, political, legal and ethical issues associated with contemporary natural resource conservation in New Zealand.

The conservation of threatened or endangered megafauna will be studied within reserves, while field
techniques will be utilised to collect data on their biology, ecology and management.

The development of skills in conducting a plant ecology field study: the collection and presentation of data. The influence of disturbance and soils on forest dynamics, patterns and causes of plant species diversity and plant Physiology.

The explanation of evolutionary drivers of animal behaviour and the practical implications of behavioural traits for conservation. The development of an understanding of animal behaviour research and practical experience in the collection of behavioural data.

An investigation of the ecology and biology of tropical marine and terrestrial ecosystems utilising practical field techniques, experimental design and analytical skills to assess the impact of human populations on these ecosystems.

Understanding of the geomorphology, ecosystems and resources associated with terrestrial, coastal and marine environments.  Critical assessment of the issues associated with resource allocation and use and the range of techniques utilized in the management of natural resources.
The use of advanced geo-spatial analysis tools for environmental management, decision support and geo-spatial planning.
Explore methods for determining the links between conservation of biodiversity, the attitudes and aspirations of people, and the success of conservation projects.

An in-depth understanding of the technical, theoretical and applied aspects of remote sensing theory as an important spatially based tool for conservation, decision support and natural resource planning and management.

Immersion in the food product development process using a product development team approach.  Identifies the processes and stages required to address a specific product development objective from concept to finished product.

Knowledge of the properties and uses of packaging materials and packaging procedures for foods; the ability to choose and evaluate packaging procedures and packaging materials and to monitor performance.

The reasons for and the development of food legislation in New Zealand; major food related legislation and enforcement agencies; the impact of international food law and trade agreements on our legislation; other factors that influence changes to our food laws.
A detailed study of the chemistry of selected food components, their identification, interactions, analysis, uses in formulations, and impact on society.

Provides an overview of sensory evaluation.  Covers special senses, as well as control of test room, samples and panel.  Reviews discriminative, descriptive and affective sensory methodolgies used to measure human perception and preference.  Description and measurement of the sensory characteristics of food products.
Methods to ensure food safety and provides students with the advanced skills to perform root cause analysis, food verification as well as auditing principles.
An introduction to the principles and applications of molecular genetics, gene manipulation and related technologies.
The practice of diagnostic molecular genetics.

The application of scientific and engineering principles to the processing of material by biological agents (i.e. microbial plant, animal cells and enzymes); the processing of biological materials such as food, medicine and chemicals; how a living cell performs a specific useful task in a predictable and controllable way.

An understanding of the microbial ecology of foods and the role of micro-organisms in food production; problems associated with sampling and micro-biological analysis of foods;  interpretation of micro-biological data; development of an assurance programme in food preparation and food manufacture.

Explores the pharmacology of commonly used drugs and the application of this to various clinical situations.  Considers the responsibilities of the health professional in relation to drug therapy and with regard to political, social, and cultural considerations, pharmacology science, legislation, and ethical practice.

An investigation into a scientific or technological problem where the student develops skills in experimental design; literature searching; the collection, treatment, interpretation and reporting of results.
Pharmacology of anaesthetic agents; anaesthetic management; fluids and blood; emergency situations.

Training in management of complex procedures in Anaesthetic Technology at an advanced level through supervised work experience; theoretical teaching in the clinical setting; completion of practical tasks through log books and practical assessments.
